docs/source/user_guide/kernel.rst:For dealing a large raw CUDA source or loading an existing CUDA binary, the :class:`~cupy.RawModule` class can be more handy. It can be initialized either by a CUDA source code, or by a path to the CUDA binary. It accepts most of the arguments as in :class:`~cupy.RawKernel`. The needed kernels can then be retrieved by calling the :meth:`~cupy.RawModule.get_function` method, which returns a :class:`~cupy.RawKernel` instance that can be invoked as discussed above.

docs/source/user_guide/kernel.rst:At the first function call, the fused function analyzes the original function based on the abstracted information of arguments (e.g. their dtypes and ndims) and creates and caches an actual CUDA kernel.  From the second function call with the same input types, the fused function calls the previously cached kernel, so it is highly recommended to reuse the same decorated functions instead of decorating local functions that are defined multiple times.

The first two entries are the grid and block sizes, respectively. ``grid`` ( RawKernel style ``(128,)`` or Numba style ``[128]``) is the sizes of the grid, i.e., the numbers of blocks in each dimension; ``block`` (``(1024,)`` or ``[1024]``) is the dimensions of each thread block, please refer to :class:`cupyx.jit._interface._JitRawKernel` for details. Launching a CUDA kernel on a GPU with pre-determined grid/block sizes requires basic understanding in the `CUDA Programming Model`_.

docs/source/user_guide/kernel.rst:CuPy's JIT compiler generates CUDA code via Python AST. We decided not to use Python bytecode to analyze the target function to avoid performance degradation. The CUDA source code generated from the Python bytecode will not effectively optimized by CUDA compiler, because for-loops and other control statements of the target function are fully transformed to jump instruction when converting the target function to bytecode.

docs/source/user_guide/fft.rst:Multi-GPU FFT
docs/source/user_guide/fft.rst:CuPy currently provides two kinds of *experimental* support for multi-GPU FFT.
docs/source/user_guide/fft.rst:    Using multiple GPUs to perform FFT is not guaranteed to be more performant. The rule of thumb is if the transform fits in 1 GPU, you should avoid using multiple.
docs/source/user_guide/fft.rst:The first kind of support is with the high-level :func:`~cupy.fft.fft` and :func:`~cupy.fft.ifft` APIs, which requires the input array to reside on one of the participating GPUs. The multi-GPU calculation is done under the hood, and by the end of the calculation the result again resides on the device where it started. Currently only 1D complex-to-complex (C2C) transform is supported; complex-to-real (C2R) or real-to-complex (R2C) transforms (such as :func:`~cupy.fft.rfft` and friends) are not. The transform can be either batched (batch size > 1) or not (batch size = 1).
docs/source/user_guide/fft.rst:    cp.fft.config.use_multi_gpus = True
docs/source/user_guide/fft.rst:    cp.fft.config.set_cufft_gpus([0, 1])  # use GPU 0 & 1
docs/source/user_guide/fft.rst:    a = cp.random.random(shape).astype(dtype)  # reside on GPU 0
docs/source/user_guide/fft.rst:    b = cp.fft.fft(a)  # computed on GPU 0 & 1, reside on GPU 0
docs/source/user_guide/fft.rst:The second kind of usage is to use the low-level, *private* CuPy APIs. You need to construct a :class:`~cupy.cuda.cufft.Plan1d` object and use it as if you are programming in C/C++ with `cuFFT`_. Using this approach, your input array can reside on the host as a :class:`numpy.ndarray` so that its size can be much larger than what a single GPU can accommodate, which is one of the main reasons to run multi-GPU FFT.
docs/source/user_guide/fft.rst:    cufft_type = cp.cuda.cufft.CUFFT_C2C  # single-precision c2c
docs/source/user_guide/fft.rst:    plan = cp.cuda.cufft.Plan1d(nx, cufft_type, batch, devices=[0,1])

docs/source/user_guide/fft.rst:`cuFFT`_ provides ``cufftXtMakePlanMany`` and ``cufftXtExec`` routines to support a wide range of FFT needs, including 64-bit indexing and half-precision FFT. CuPy provides an *experimental* support for this capability via the new (though *private*) :class:`~cupy.cuda.cufft.XtPlanNd` API. For half-precision FFT, on supported hardware it can be twice as fast than its single-precision counterpart. NumPy does not yet provide the necessary infrastructure for half-precision complex numbers (i.e., ``numpy.complex32``), though, so the steps for this feature is currently a bit more involved than common cases.

docs/source/user_guide/performance.rst:CuPy uses on-the-fly kernel synthesis. When a kernel call is required, it compiles a kernel code optimized for the dimensions and dtypes of the given arguments, sends them to the GPU device, and executes the kernel.
docs/source/user_guide/performance.rst:CuPy caches the kernel code sent to GPU device within the process, which reduces the kernel compilation time on further calls.
docs/source/user_guide/performance.rst:For reduction operations (such as :func:`~cupy.sum`, :func:`~cupy.prod`, :func:`~cupy.amin`, :func:`~cupy.amax`, :func:`~cupy.argmin`, :func:`~cupy.argmax`) and many more routines built upon them, CuPy ships with our own implementations so that things just work out of the box. However, there are dedicated efforts to further accelerate these routines, such as `CUB <https://github.com/NVIDIA/cub>`_ and `cuTENSOR <https://developer.nvidia.com/cutensor>`_.

docs/source/user_guide/interoperability.rst:MPI is the most widely used standard for high-performance inter-process communications. Recently several MPI vendors, including MPICH, Open MPI and MVAPICH, have extended their support beyond the MPI-3.1 standard to enable "CUDA-awareness"; that is, passing CUDA device pointers directly to MPI calls to avoid explicit data movement between the host and the device.
docs/source/user_guide/interoperability.rst:With the ``__cuda_array_interface__`` (as mentioned above) and ``DLPack`` data exchange protocols (see :ref:`dlpack` below) implemented in CuPy, mpi4py now provides (experimental) support for passing CuPy arrays to MPI calls, provided that mpi4py is built against a CUDA-aware MPI implementation. The following is a simple example code borrowed from `mpi4py Tutorial <https://mpi4py.readthedocs.io/en/latest/tutorial.html>`_:
docs/source/user_guide/interoperability.rst:PyTorch also supports ``__cuda_array_interface__``, so zero-copy data exchange between CuPy and PyTorch can be achieved at no cost.

docs/source/user_guide/interoperability.rst:users need to ensure the tensor is already on GPU before exchanging.

docs/source/reference/fft.rst:Internally, ``cupy.fft`` always generates a *cuFFT plan* (see the `cuFFT documentation`_ for detail) corresponding to the desired transform. When possible, an n-dimensional plan will be used, as opposed to applying separate 1D plans for each axis to be transformed. Using n-dimensional planning can provide better performance for multidimensional transforms, but requires more GPU memory than separable 1D planning. The user can disable n-dimensional planning by setting ``cupy.fft.config.enable_nd_planning = False``. This ability to adjust the planning type is a deviation from the NumPy API, which does not use precomputed FFT plans.
docs/source/reference/fft.rst:Multi-GPU FFT
docs/source/reference/fft.rst::mod:`cupy.fft` can use multiple GPUs. To enable (disable) this feature, set :data:`cupy.fft.config.use_multi_gpus` to ``True`` (``False``). Next, to set the number of GPUs or the participating GPU IDs, use the function :func:`cupy.fft.config.set_cufft_gpus`. All of the limitations listed in the `cuFFT documentation`_ apply here. In particular, using more than one GPU does not guarantee better performance.

docs/source/reference/environment.rst:  If set to ``1``, CuPy will use the CUDA per-thread default stream, effectively causing each host thread to automatically execute in its own stream, unless the CUDA default (``null``) stream or a user-created stream is specified.
docs/source/reference/environment.rst:  If set to ``0`` (default), the CUDA default (``null``) stream is used, unless the per-thread default stream (``ptds``) or a user-created stream is specified.
docs/source/reference/environment.rst:  By default, CuPy directly compiles kernels into SASS (CUBIN) to support `CUDA Enhanced Compatibility <https://docs.nvidia.com/deploy/cuda-compatibility/>`_
docs/source/reference/environment.rst:  If set to ``1``, CuPy instead compiles kernels into PTX and lets CUDA Driver assemble SASS from PTX.
docs/source/reference/environment.rst:  This option is only effective for CUDA 11.1 or later; CuPy always compiles into PTX on earlier CUDA versions. Also, this option only applies when NVRTC is selected as the compilation backend. NVCC backend always compiles into SASS (CUBIN).

docs/source/install.rst:Windows once the CUDA driver is correctly set up, you can also install CuPy from the ``conda-forge`` channel::
docs/source/install.rst:and ``conda`` will install a pre-built CuPy binary package for you, along with the CUDA runtime libraries
docs/source/install.rst:(``cudatoolkit`` for CUDA 11 and below, or ``cuda-XXXXX`` for CUDA 12 and above). It is not necessary to install CUDA Toolkit in advance.
docs/source/install.rst:which only depends on ``numpy``. None of the CUDA libraries will be installed this way, and it is your responsibility to install the needed
docs/source/install.rst:dependencies yourself, either from conda-forge or elsewhere. This is equivalent of the ``cupy-cudaXX`` wheel installation.
docs/source/install.rst:Conda has a built-in mechanism to determine and install the latest version of ``cudatoolkit`` or any other CUDA components supported by your driver.
docs/source/install.rst:However, if for any reason you need to force-install a particular CUDA version (say 11.8), you can do::
docs/source/install.rst:    $ conda install -c conda-forge cupy cuda-version=11.8
docs/source/install.rst:    cuDNN, cuTENSOR, and NCCL are available on ``conda-forge`` as optional dependencies. The following command can install them all at once::
docs/source/install.rst:        $ conda install -c conda-forge cupy cudnn cutensor nccl
docs/source/install.rst:    If you did not install CUDA Toolkit by yourself, for CUDA 11 and below the ``nvcc`` compiler might not be available, as
docs/source/install.rst:    the ``cudatoolkit`` package from ``conda-forge`` does not include the ``nvcc`` compiler toolchain. If you would like to use
docs/source/install.rst:    it from a local CUDA installation, you need to make sure the version of CUDA Toolkit matches that of ``cudatoolkit`` to
docs/source/install.rst:    avoid surprises. For CUDA 12 and above, ``nvcc`` can be installed on a per-``conda`` environment basis via
docs/source/install.rst:        $ conda install -c conda-forge cuda-nvcc
docs/source/install.rst:However, if wheels cannot meet your requirements (e.g., you are running non-Linux environment or want to use a version of CUDA / cuDNN / NCCL not supported by wheels), you can also build CuPy from source.
docs/source/install.rst:   When installing CuPy from source, features provided by additional CUDA libraries will be disabled if these libraries are not available at the build time.
docs/source/install.rst:   If you upgrade or downgrade the version of CUDA Toolkit, cuDNN, NCCL or cuTENSOR, you may need to reinstall CuPy.
docs/source/install.rst:   If you are using a wheel, ``cupy`` shall be replaced with ``cupy-cudaXX`` (where XX is a CUDA version number).

docs/source/install.rst:Use `NVIDIA Container Toolkit <https://github.com/NVIDIA/nvidia-docker>`_ to run CuPy image with GPU.
docs/source/install.rst:  $ docker run --gpus all -it cupy/cupy /bin/bash
docs/source/install.rst:  $ docker run --gpus all -it cupy/cupy /usr/bin/python3
docs/source/install.rst:If you need to pass environment variable (e.g., ``CUDA_PATH``), you need to specify them inside ``sudo`` like this::
docs/source/install.rst:  $ sudo CUDA_PATH=/opt/nvidia/cuda pip install cupy
docs/source/install.rst:Installing cuDNN and NCCL
docs/source/install.rst:We recommend installing cuDNN and NCCL using binary packages (i.e., using ``apt`` or ``yum``) provided by NVIDIA.
docs/source/install.rst:If you want to install tar-gz version of cuDNN and NCCL, we recommend installing it under the ``CUDA_PATH`` directory.
docs/source/install.rst:  $ cp /path/to/cudnn.h $CUDA_PATH/include
docs/source/install.rst:  $ cp /path/to/libcudnn.so* $CUDA_PATH/lib64
docs/source/install.rst:If you want to use cuDNN or NCCL installed in another directory, please use ``CFLAGS``, ``LDFLAGS`` and ``LD_LIBRARY_PATH`` environment variables before installing CuPy::
docs/source/install.rst:.. _install_cuda:
docs/source/install.rst:Working with Custom CUDA Installation
docs/source/install.rst:If you have installed CUDA on the non-default directory or multiple CUDA versions on the same host, you may need to manually specify the CUDA installation directory to be used by CuPy.
docs/source/install.rst:CuPy uses the first CUDA installation directory found by the following order.
docs/source/install.rst:#. ``CUDA_PATH`` environment variable.
docs/source/install.rst:#. ``/usr/local/cuda``
docs/source/install.rst:For example, you can build CuPy using non-default CUDA directory by ``CUDA_PATH`` environment variable::
docs/source/install.rst:  $ CUDA_PATH=/opt/nvidia/cuda pip install cupy
docs/source/install.rst:   CUDA installation discovery is also performed at runtime using the rule above.
docs/source/install.rst:   Depending on your system configuration, you may also need to set ``LD_LIBRARY_PATH`` environment variable to ``$CUDA_PATH/lib64`` at runtime.
docs/source/install.rst:On CUDA 12.2 or later, CUDA Runtime header files are required to compile kernels in CuPy.
docs/source/install.rst:This problem does not happen if you have installed CuPy from conda-forge (i.e., ``conda install -c conda-forge cupy``), as the package ``cuda-cudart-dev_<platform>`` that contains the needed headers is correctly installed as a dependency.
docs/source/install.rst:If you have installed CuPy from PyPI (i.e., ``pip install cupy-cuda12x``), you can install CUDA headers by running ``pip install "nvidia-cuda-runtime-cu12==12.X.*"`` where ``12.X`` is the version of your CUDA installation.
docs/source/install.rst:Once headers from the package is recognized, ``cupy.show_config()`` will display the path as ``CUDA Extra Include Dirs``:
docs/source/install.rst:  CUDA Extra Include Dirs      : []
docs/source/install.rst:  $ pip install "nvidia-cuda-runtime-cu12==12.6.*"
docs/source/install.rst:  CUDA Extra Include Dirs      : ['.../site-packages/nvidia/cuda_runtime/include']
docs/source/install.rst:Alternatively, you can install CUDA headers system-wide (``/usr/local/cuda``) using NVIDIA's Apt (or DNF) repository.
docs/source/install.rst:Install the ``cuda-cudart-dev-12-X`` package where ``12-X`` is the version of your ``cuda-cudart`` package, e.g.:
docs/source/install.rst:  $ apt list "cuda-cudart-*"
docs/source/install.rst:  cuda-cudart-12-6/now 12.6.68-1 amd64 [installed,local]
docs/source/install.rst:  $ sudo apt install "cuda-cudart-dev-12-6"
docs/source/install.rst:CuPy always raises ``cupy.cuda.compiler.CompileException``
docs/source/install.rst:If CuPy raises a ``CompileException`` for almost everything, it is possible that CuPy cannot detect CUDA installed on your system correctly.
docs/source/install.rst:* ``catastrophic error: cannot open source file "cuda_fp16.h"``
docs/source/install.rst:Please try setting ``LD_LIBRARY_PATH`` and ``CUDA_PATH`` environment variable.
docs/source/install.rst:For example, if you have CUDA installed at ``/usr/local/cuda-12.6``::
docs/source/install.rst:  $ export CUDA_PATH=/usr/local/cuda-12.6
docs/source/install.rst:  $ export LD_LIBRARY_PATH=$CUDA_PATH/lib64:$LD_LIBRARY_PATH
docs/source/install.rst:Also see :ref:`install_cuda`.
docs/source/install.rst:Using CuPy on AMD GPU (experimental)
docs/source/install.rst:CuPy has an experimental support for AMD GPU (ROCm).
docs/source/install.rst:* `AMD GPU supported by ROCm <https://github.com/RadeonOpenCompute/ROCm#Hardware-and-Software-Support>`_
docs/source/install.rst:* `ROCm <https://rocmdocs.amd.com/en/latest/index.html>`_: v4.3 / v5.0
docs/source/install.rst:    * See the `ROCm Installation Guide <https://rocmdocs.amd.com/en/latest/Installation_Guide/Installation-Guide.html>`_ for details.
docs/source/install.rst:The following ROCm libraries are required:
docs/source/install.rst:When building or running CuPy for ROCm, the following environment variables are effective.
docs/source/install.rst:* ``ROCM_HOME``: directory containing the ROCm software (e.g., ``/opt/rocm``).
docs/source/install.rst:You can try running CuPy for ROCm using Docker.
docs/source/install.rst:  $ docker run -it --device=/dev/kfd --device=/dev/dri --group-add video cupy/cupy-rocm
docs/source/install.rst:Package names are different depending on your ROCm version.
docs/source/install.rst:   * - ROCm
docs/source/install.rst:     - ``$ pip install cupy-rocm-4-3``
docs/source/install.rst:     - ``$ pip install cupy-rocm-5-0``
docs/source/install.rst:Building CuPy for ROCm From Source
docs/source/install.rst:To build CuPy from source, set the ``CUPY_INSTALL_USE_HIP``, ``ROCM_HOME``, and ``HCC_AMDGPU_TARGET`` environment variables.
docs/source/install.rst:(``HCC_AMDGPU_TARGET`` is the ISA name supported by your GPU.
docs/source/install.rst:Run ``rocminfo`` and use the value displayed in ``Name:`` line (e.g., ``gfx900``).
docs/source/install.rst:You can specify a comma-separated list of ISAs if you have multiple GPUs of different architectures.)
docs/source/install.rst:  $ export ROCM_HOME=/opt/rocm
docs/source/install.rst:  $ export HCC_AMDGPU_TARGET=gfx906
docs/source/install.rst:  If you don't specify the ``HCC_AMDGPU_TARGET`` environment variable, CuPy will be built for the GPU architectures available on the build host.
docs/source/install.rst:  This behavior is specific to ROCm builds; when building CuPy for NVIDIA CUDA, the build result is not affected by the host configuration.
docs/source/install.rst:The following features are not available due to the limitation of ROCm or because that they are specific to CUDA:
docs/source/install.rst:* CUDA Array Interface
docs/source/install.rst:* Multi-GPU FFT and FFT callback
docs/source/install.rst:   CuPy's issues, but ROCm may have some potential bugs.

docs/source/upgrade.rst:NVIDIA's CUDA C++ Core Libraries (CCCL) is the new home for the inter-dependent C++ libraries Thrust, CUB, and libcu++ that are shipped
docs/source/upgrade.rst:with CUDA Toolkit 11.0+. To better serve our users with the latest CCCL features, improvements, and bug fixes, starting CuPy v13
docs/source/upgrade.rst:CuPy) and run-time (for JIT-compiling kernels). This ensures uniform behavior, avoids surprises, and allows dual CUDA support as promised
docs/source/upgrade.rst:by CCCL (currently CUDA 11 & 12), but this change leads to the following consequences distinct from the past releases:
docs/source/upgrade.rst:* the CCCL from any local CUDA installation is now ignored on purpose, either at build- or run- time;
docs/source/upgrade.rst:As a result of this movement, CuPy now follows the same compiler requirement as CCCL (and, in turn, CUDA Toolkit) and requires C++11 as
docs/source/upgrade.rst:* CUDA 11.1 or earlier
docs/source/upgrade.rst:When transferring a CuPy array from GPU to CPU (as a NumPy array), previously the transfer could be nonblocking and not properly ordered when a non-default stream is in use,
docs/source/upgrade.rst:When transferring a NumPy array from CPU to GPU, previously the transfer was always blocking even if the source array is backed by pinned memory.
docs/source/upgrade.rst:* An *internal and undocumented* API :func:`cupy.cuda.compile_with_cache`, which was marked deprecated in CuPy v10, has been removed.
docs/source/upgrade.rst:CUDA Runtime API is now statically linked
docs/source/upgrade.rst:CuPy is now shipped with CUDA Runtime statically linked.
docs/source/upgrade.rst:Due to this, :func:`cupy.cuda.runtime.runtimeGetVersion` always returns the version of CUDA Runtime that CuPy is built with, regardless of the version of CUDA Runtime installed locally.
docs/source/upgrade.rst:If you need to retrieve the version of CUDA Runtime shared library installed locally, use :func:`cupy.cuda.get_local_runtime_version` instead.
docs/source/upgrade.rst:CuPy official Docker images (see :doc:`install` for details) are now updated to use CUDA 12.2.
docs/source/upgrade.rst:Change in :class:`cupy.cuda.Device` Behavior
docs/source/upgrade.rst:The CUDA current device (set via :meth:`cupy.cuda.Device.use()` or ``cudaSetDevice()``) will be reactivated when exiting a device context manager.
docs/source/upgrade.rst:This decision was made for better interoperability with other libraries that might mutate the current CUDA device.
docs/source/upgrade.rst:       with cupy.cuda.Device(2):
docs/source/upgrade.rst:   torch.cuda.set_device(1)
docs/source/upgrade.rst:   print(torch.cuda.get_device())  # -> ???
docs/source/upgrade.rst:CuPy official Docker images (see :doc:`install` for details) are now updated to use CUDA 11.8.
docs/source/upgrade.rst:Unified Binary Package for CUDA 11.2+
docs/source/upgrade.rst:CuPy v11 provides a unified binary package named ``cupy-cuda11x`` that supports all CUDA 11.2+ releases.
docs/source/upgrade.rst:This replaces per-CUDA version binary packages (``cupy-cuda112`` ~ ``cupy-cuda117``).
docs/source/upgrade.rst:Note that CUDA 11.1 or earlier still requires per-CUDA version binary packages.
docs/source/upgrade.rst:``cupy-cuda102``, ``cupy-cuda110``, and ``cupy-cuda111`` will be provided for CUDA 10.2, 11.0, and 11.1, respectively.
docs/source/upgrade.rst:* ROCm 4.2 or earlier
docs/source/upgrade.rst:CuPy official Docker images (see :doc:`install` for details) are now updated to use CUDA 11.7 and ROCm 5.0.
docs/source/upgrade.rst:Dropping CUDA 9.2 / 10.0 / 10.1 Support
docs/source/upgrade.rst:CUDA 10.1 or earlier is no longer supported.
docs/source/upgrade.rst:Use CUDA 10.2 or later.
docs/source/upgrade.rst:Dropping NCCL v2.4 / v2.6 / v2.7 Support
docs/source/upgrade.rst:NCCL v2.4, v2.6, and v2.7 are no longer supported.
docs/source/upgrade.rst:Change in :class:`cupy.cuda.Device` Behavior
docs/source/upgrade.rst:Current device set via :meth:`~cupy.cuda.Device.use` will not be honored by the ``with Device`` block
docs/source/upgrade.rst:The current device set via :meth:`cupy.cuda.Device.use()` will not be reactivated when exiting a device context manager. An existing code mixing ``with device:`` block and ``device.use()`` may get different results between CuPy v10 and v9.
docs/source/upgrade.rst:   cupy.cuda.Device(1).use()
docs/source/upgrade.rst:   with cupy.cuda.Device(0):
docs/source/upgrade.rst:   cupy.cuda.Device()  # -> CuPy v10 returns device 0 instead of device 1
docs/source/upgrade.rst:as essentially CuPy's :class:`~cupy.cuda.Device` context manager no longer respects the CUDA ``cudaSetDevice()`` API. Mixing
docs/source/upgrade.rst:For downstream libraries that still wish to respect the ``cudaGetDevice()``/``cudaSetDevice()`` APIs, you should avoid managing
docs/source/upgrade.rst:Changes in :class:`cupy.cuda.Stream` Behavior
docs/source/upgrade.rst:Previoulys, it was users' responsibility to keep the current stream consistent with the current CUDA device.

docs/source/upgrade.rst:The same :class:`cupy.cuda.Stream` instance can now safely be shared between multiple threads.
docs/source/upgrade.rst:To achieve this, CuPy v10 will not destroy the stream (``cudaStreamDestroy``) if the stream is the current stream of any thread.
docs/source/upgrade.rst::func:`cupy.array`, :func:`cupy.asarray` and its variants now always transfer the data to GPU in little-endian byte order.
docs/source/upgrade.rst:Previously CuPy was copying the given :class:`numpy.ndarray` to GPU as-is, regardless of the endianness.
docs/source/upgrade.rst:In CuPy v10, big-endian arrays are converted to little-endian before the transfer, which is the native byte order on GPUs.
docs/source/upgrade.rst:* An *internal* API :func:`cupy.cuda.compile_with_cache` has been marked as deprecated as there are better alternatives (see :class:`~cupy.RawModule` added since CuPy v7 and :class:`~cupy.RawKernel` since v5). While it has a longstanding history, this API has never been meant to be public. We encourage downstream libraries and users to migrate to the aforementioned public APIs. See :doc:`./user_guide/kernel` for their tutorials.
docs/source/upgrade.rst:    * :func:`cupy.cuda.profile` -> :func:`cupyx.profiler.profile`
docs/source/upgrade.rst:CuPy official Docker images (see :doc:`install` for details) are now updated to use CUDA 11.4 and ROCm 4.3.
docs/source/upgrade.rst:Dropping Support of CUDA 9.0
docs/source/upgrade.rst:CUDA 9.0 is no longer supported.
docs/source/upgrade.rst:Use CUDA 9.2 or later.
docs/source/upgrade.rst:Dropping Support of cuDNN v7.5 and NCCL v2.3
docs/source/upgrade.rst:cuDNN v7.5 (or earlier) and NCCL v2.3 (or earlier) are no longer supported.
docs/source/upgrade.rst:NCCL and cuDNN No Longer Included in Wheels
docs/source/upgrade.rst:NCCL and cuDNN shared libraries are no longer included in wheels (see `#4850 <https://github.com/cupy/cupy/issues/4850>`_ for discussions). 
docs/source/upgrade.rst:``cupy.cuda.{nccl,cudnn}`` Modules Needs Explicit Import
docs/source/upgrade.rst:Previously ``cupy.cuda.nccl`` and ``cupy.cuda.cudnn`` modules were automatically imported.
docs/source/upgrade.rst:Since CuPy v9, these modules need to be explicitly imported (i.e., ``import cupy.cuda.nccl`` / ``import cupy.cuda.cudnn``.)
docs/source/upgrade.rst:CuPy official Docker images (see :doc:`install` for details) are now updated to use CUDA 11.2 and Python 3.8.
docs/source/upgrade.rst:Dropping Support of CUDA 8.0 and 9.1
docs/source/upgrade.rst:CUDA 8.0 and 9.1 are no longer supported.
docs/source/upgrade.rst:Use CUDA 9.0, 9.2, 10.0, or later.
docs/source/upgrade.rst:* CuPy official Docker images (see :doc:`install` for details) are now updated to use CUDA 10.2 and Python 3.6.
docs/source/upgrade.rst:* ``CUB_PATH``: No longer required as CuPy uses either the CUB source bundled with CUDA (only when using CUDA 11.0 or later) or the one in the CuPy distribution.
docs/source/upgrade.rst:* :func:`cupy.allclose` now returns the result as 0-dim GPU array instead of Python bool to avoid device synchronization.
docs/source/upgrade.rst:* ``cupy.cuda.*_enabled`` flags (``nccl_enabled``, ``nvtx_enabled``, etc.) has been deprecated. Use ``cupy.cuda.*.available`` flag (``cupy.cuda.nccl.available``, ``cupy.cuda.nvtx.available``, etc.) instead.
docs/source/upgrade.rst:Prior to CuPy v6, ``LD_LIBRARY_PATH`` environment variable can be used to override cuDNN / NCCL libraries bundled in the binary distribution (also known as wheels).
docs/source/upgrade.rst:In CuPy v6, ``LD_LIBRARY_PATH`` will be ignored during discovery of cuDNN / NCCL; CuPy binary distributions always use libraries that comes with the package to avoid errors caused by unexpected override.
docs/source/upgrade.rst::mod:`cupyx.scipy` namespace has been introduced to provide CUDA-enabled SciPy functions.
docs/source/upgrade.rst:Dropped Support for CUDA 7.0 / 7.5
docs/source/upgrade.rst:CuPy v5 no longer supports CUDA 7.0 / 7.5.
docs/source/upgrade.rst:CuPy official Docker images (see :doc:`install` for details) are now updated to use CUDA 9.2 and cuDNN 7.
docs/source/upgrade.rst:To use these images, you may need to upgrade the NVIDIA driver on your host.
docs/source/upgrade.rst:See `Requirements of nvidia-docker <https://github.com/NVIDIA/nvidia-docker/wiki/CUDA#requirements>`_ for details.
docs/source/upgrade.rst:The memory pool significantly improves the performance by mitigating the overhead of memory allocation and CPU/GPU synchronization.
docs/source/upgrade.rst:   When you monitor GPU memory usage (e.g., using ``nvidia-smi``), you may notice that GPU memory not being freed even after the array instance become out of scope.

docs/source/upgrade.rst:CuPy v4 now requires NVIDIA GPU with Compute Capability 3.0 or larger.
docs/source/upgrade.rst:See the `List of CUDA GPUs <https://developer.nvidia.com/cuda-gpus>`_ to check if your GPU supports Compute Capability 3.0.
docs/source/upgrade.rst:CUDA Stream
docs/source/upgrade.rst:As CUDA Stream is fully supported in CuPy v4, ``cupy.cuda.RandomState.set_stream``, the function to change the stream used by the random number generator, has been removed.
docs/source/upgrade.rst:Please use :func:`cupy.cuda.Stream.use` instead.
docs/source/upgrade.rst:CuPy official Docker images (see :doc:`install` for details) are now updated to use CUDA 8.0 and cuDNN 6.0.
docs/source/upgrade.rst:This change was introduced because CUDA 7.5 does not support NVIDIA Pascal GPUs.
docs/source/upgrade.rst:To use these images, you may need to upgrade the NVIDIA driver on your host.

docs/source/overview.rst:`CuPy <https://github.com/cupy/cupy>`__ is a NumPy/SciPy-compatible array library for GPU-accelerated computing with Python.
docs/source/overview.rst:CuPy acts as a drop-in replacement to run existing NumPy/SciPy code on `NVIDIA CUDA <https://developer.nvidia.com/cuda-toolkit>`__ or `AMD ROCm <https://www.amd.com/en/graphics/servers-solutions-rocm>`__ platforms.
docs/source/overview.rst:CuPy provides a ``ndarray``, sparse matrices, and the associated routines for GPU devices, all having the same API as NumPy and SciPy:
docs/source/overview.rst:Routines are backed by CUDA libraries (cuBLAS, cuFFT, cuSPARSE, cuSOLVER, cuRAND), Thrust, CUB, and cuTENSOR to provide the best performance.
docs/source/overview.rst:It is also possible to easily implement :doc:`custom CUDA kernels <user_guide/kernel>` that work with ``ndarray`` using:
docs/source/overview.rst:* **Kernel Templates**: Quickly define element-wise and reduction operation as a single CUDA kernel
docs/source/overview.rst:* **Raw Kernel**: Import existing CUDA C/C++ code
docs/source/overview.rst:* **Just-in-time Transpiler (JIT)**: Generate CUDA kernel from Python source code
docs/source/overview.rst:* **Kernel Fusion**: Fuse multiple CuPy operations into a single CUDA kernel
docs/source/overview.rst:CuPy can run in multi-GPU or cluster environments. The distributed communication package (:mod:`cupyx.distributed`) provides collective and peer-to-peer primitives for ``ndarray``, backed by NCCL.
docs/source/overview.rst:For users who need more fine-grain control for performance, accessing :doc:`low-level CUDA features <user_guide/cuda_api>` are available:
docs/source/overview.rst:* **Stream and Event**: CUDA stream and per-thread default stream are supported by all APIs
docs/source/overview.rst:* **Profiler**: Supports profiling code using CUDA Profiler and NVTX
docs/source/overview.rst:* **Host API Binding**: Directly call CUDA libraries, such as NCCL, cuDNN, cuTENSOR, and cuSPARSELt APIs from Python
docs/source/overview.rst:CuPy implements standard APIs for data exchange and interoperability, such as `DLPack <https://github.com/dmlc/dlpack>`__, `CUDA Array Interface <https://numba.readthedocs.io/en/stable/cuda/cuda_array_interface.html>`__, ``__array_ufunc__`` (`NEP 13 <https://numpy.org/neps/nep-0013-ufunc-overrides.html>`__), ``__array_function__`` (`NEP 18 <https://numpy.org/neps/nep-0018-array-function-protocol.html>`__), and `Array API Standard <https://data-apis.org/array-api/latest/>`__.
docs/source/overview.rst:Under AMD ROCm environment, CuPy automatically translates all CUDA API calls to ROCm HIP (hipBLAS, hipFFT, hipSPARSE, hipRAND, hipCUB, hipThrust, RCCL, etc.), allowing code written using CuPy to run on both NVIDIA and AMD GPU without any modification.
docs/source/overview.rst:The goal of the CuPy project is to provide Python users GPU acceleration capabilities, without the in-depth knowledge of underlying GPU technologies.
docs/source/overview.rst:* A complete NumPy and SciPy API coverage to become a full drop-in replacement, as well as advanced CUDA features to maximize the performance.

README.md:# CuPy : NumPy & SciPy for GPU
README.md:CuPy is a NumPy/SciPy-compatible array library for GPU-accelerated computing with Python.
README.md:CuPy acts as a [drop-in replacement](https://docs.cupy.dev/en/stable/reference/comparison.html) to run existing NumPy/SciPy code on NVIDIA CUDA or AMD ROCm platforms.
README.md:CuPy also provides access to low-level CUDA features.
README.md:You can pass `ndarray` to existing CUDA C/C++ programs via [RawKernels](https://docs.cupy.dev/en/stable/user_guide/kernel.html#raw-kernels), use [Streams](https://docs.cupy.dev/en/stable/reference/cuda.html) for performance, or even call [CUDA Runtime APIs](https://docs.cupy.dev/en/stable/reference/cuda.html#runtime-api) directly.
README.md:| CUDA 11.x (11.2+)     | x86_64 / aarch64  | `pip install cupy-cuda11x`                                    |
README.md:| CUDA 12.x             | x86_64 / aarch64  | `pip install cupy-cuda12x`                                    |
README.md:| ROCm 4.3 (*[experimental](https://docs.cupy.dev/en/latest/install.html#using-cupy-on-amd-gpu-experimental)*)          | x86_64            | `pip install cupy-rocm-4-3`                                   |
README.md:| ROCm 5.0 (*[experimental](https://docs.cupy.dev/en/latest/install.html#using-cupy-on-amd-gpu-experimental)*)          | x86_64            | `pip install cupy-rocm-5-0`                                   |
README.md:> To install pre-releases, append `--pre -U -f https://pip.cupy.dev/pre` (e.g., `pip install cupy-cuda11x --pre -U -f https://pip.cupy.dev/pre`).
README.md:| CUDA                  | x86_64 / aarch64 / ppc64le  | `conda install -c conda-forge cupy`                           |
README.md:If you need a slim installation (without also getting CUDA dependencies installed), you can do `conda install -c conda-forge cupy-core`.
README.md:If you need to use a particular CUDA version (say 12.0), you can use the `cuda-version` metapackage to select the version, e.g. `conda install -c conda-forge cupy cuda-version=12.0`.
README.md:Use [NVIDIA Container Toolkit](https://docs.nvidia.com/datacenter/cloud-native/container-toolkit/overview.html) to run [CuPy container images](https://hub.docker.com/r/cupy/cupy).
README.md:$ docker run --gpus all -it cupy/cupy
README.md:- [GPU Acceleration in Python using CuPy and Numba (GTC November 2021 Technical Session)](https://www.nvidia.com/en-us/on-demand/session/gtcfall21-a31149/)
README.md:- [GPU-Acceleration of Signal Processing Workflows using CuPy and cuSignal[^1] (ICASSP'21 Tutorial)](https://github.com/awthomp/cusignal-icassp-tutorial)
